description.p: The pKa and positive cooperativity values for the Φ functional groups of glutamic acid (Glu, E) and lysine (Lys, K) for this family of ECMP are given in Table 3 where the hydrophobic-induced reduction potential and positive cooperativity shifts are listed. The F represents the phenyalanine (Phe) residue having in the design replaced a V (valine, Val) residue. These polymers were biosynthesized using recombinant DNA technology and expressed by E. coli fermentation.

Decoration of the surface of drug-laden ECMP nanoparticles as described herein is useful for the purpose of targeting the drug delivery vehicle to the desired cell for localized drug release. One example of an entity with which to target would be synthetic antigen-binding Fab1-Fab2 fragments that target cancerous cells with up-regulated estrogen receptors. HIGH AFFINITY MONOCLONAL ANTIBODY FOR RECOGNIZING THE ESTROGEN RECEPTOR (ER) AND METHOD FOR CREATING THE ANTIBODY is taught in U.S. Pat. No. 7,148,332, and in U.S. Pat. No. 7,745,230 “ESTROGEN RECEPTORS AND METHODS OF USE CONTINUING APPLICATION DATA” which application claims the benefit of U.S. Provisional Application Ser. No. 60/552,067, filed 10 Mar. 2004, and 60/643,469, filed 13 Jan. 2005, and is under study, e.g., Use of a Monoclonal Anti-Estrogen Receptor Antibody in the Immunohistochemical Evaluation of Human Tumorsl, Cancer Research (Suppl.) 46, 4244s-4248s, August 1986, Kenneth S. McCarty, Jr., Eva Szabo, Julie L. Flowers, Edwin B. Cox, George S. Leight, Larry Miller, John Konrath, John T. Soper, Debra A. Budwit, William T. Creasman, lilluni F. Seigier, and Kenneth S. McCarty, Sr.; and Immunocytochemical Analysis of Estrogen Receptors as a Predictor of Prognosis in Breast Cancer Patients: Comparison with Quantitative Biochemical Methods1 Cancer Research 49, 1052-1056, Feb. 15, 1989, Laura B. Kinsel, Eva Szabo, Geoffrey L. Greene, John Konrath, George S. Leight, and Kenneth S. McCarty, Jr. Also, sequences of Fab1 and Fab2 fragments for binding to the estrogen receptor may be obtained by such as The Kabat Database of Sequences of Proteins of Immunological Interest. The Fab 1 and Fab2 sequences would be added to the DNA sequence, each for a designed ECMP, such that the amino end of ECMP sequences would be contiguous with the carboxyl end of the Fab. These Fab-ECMP would be incorporated into the drug-delivery nanoparticle at the desired percentage of surface coverage.

To give a sense of the length of the ECMP in comparison with the nanoparticle diameter, if laid out in the dynamic β-spiral conformation, the ECMP would be longer than the diameter of a 50 nm diameter nanoparticle. Now the 1.8 nm diameter β-spiral conformation can fold back on itself and it is believed that three β-spirals supercoil to form a twisted filament of 5 nm diameter that can be seen in electron micrographs of negatively stained filaments (See FIGS. 5, 6, and 7 of Dan W. Urry, “Free Energy Transduction in Polypeptides and Proteins Based on Inverse Temperature Transitions,” Prog. Biophys. Molec. Biol. 57, 23-57, 1992). Furthermore, as seen in FIGS. 25 and 26, the dimensions of the synthetic antigen-binding Fab1-Fab2 fragment, based on crystallographic data, would be 7 nm in length and grossly characterized as an elliptical cylinder with a 5.2 nm major axis and 3.3 nm minor axis that would jut out of the spherical nanoparticle along the axis of a diameter.

50 nm diameter cationic drug delivery nanoparticles (ECMPdd) were constructed (See FIG. 24). These nanoparticles were of the ECMP, (GVGVP GVGFP GEGFP GVGVP GVGFP GFGFP)42 (GVGVP) (SEQ ID NO:7), which is 253 pentamers. The ECMP (GVGVP GVGFP GKGFP GVGVP GVGFP GFGFP)45 (GVGVP) (SEQ ID NO:23) was also constructed. By way of example, one gene will be constructed by utilizing the appropriate restriction site to attach the gene for Fab1 to the DNA sequence encoding for a protein-based polymer to give Fab1-(GVGVP GVGFP GEGFP GVGVP GVGFP GFGFP)42 (GVGVP) (SEQ ID NO:7) labeled (ECMPdd/Fab 1). A second gene will be prepared to produce Fab2-(GVGVP GVGFP GKGFP GVGVP GVGFP GFGFP)45 (GVGVP) (SEQ ID NO:23), identified as (Fab2ECMPdd). Then the gene products, ECMP−dd/Fab1 and ECMP+dd/Fab2, are to be combined in a 1:1 ratio in dilute solution to form the associated ECMP−dd/Fab1-Fab2ECMP+dd, yielding synthetic antigen binding fragments oriented appropriately to bind the antigenic site of an upregulated receptor of a cancerous cell.

The ECMP−dd/Fab 1-Fab2ECMP+dd are added to the particular ECMPdd at a ratio to give the desired extent of decoration on the surface of the nanoparticle and the properties of the ECMP are such that they exclude the more polar Fab1-Fab2 protein by an apolar-polar repulsive free energy of hydration, ΔGap, from the interior to the charged surface of the nanoparticle. The surface area of a 50 nm diameter is 7,854 nm2, and the area occupied by the Fab1-Fab2 is about 53 nm2 such that 10% coverage of the surface would involve 15 Fab1-Fab2 constructs and 20% coverage of the surface would require 30 Fab1-Fab2 constructs. Each surface construct, a synthetic antigen-binding fragment, could be grossly described as a cylinder 7 nm in length aligned on a radial extension pointing directly out of the spherical nanoparticle surface (See FIG. 26). The cylinder may be approximated with an elliptical cross-section of a 5.2 nm major axis and a 3.3 nm minor axis with the major axis twisted by about 100° (See FIG. 25). The distal end of the cylinder would contain the antigen-binding site, which is seen in gray scale as a largely black end of the cylinder, that is an extremely hydrophobic end inserts into the antigenic site of the receptor (See FIG. 25).
description.heading: Construction of ECMP-nanoparticles (ECMPddnp) for Controlled Drug Release
description.p: By way of example a most hydrophobic composition with all V replaced by F will be used which would give the lowest, most-prolonged release profile. This is the example of the bottom curve in FIG. 3 of (GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)n (SEQ ID NO:24). Then subsequent less hydrophobic ECMP can be considered by simply decreasing the number of V replaced by F. The n for (GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)n (SEQ ID NO:24), labeled ECMP2E/10F, could vary from 0.5 to 100, but for the nanoparticle purposes considered here 30 to 60 would be preferred. The nanoparticle size is dependent on the temperature and concentration at which quenching is carried out (F. Sciortino, M. U. Palma, D. W. Urry and K. U. Prasad, “Nucleation and Accretion of Bioelastomeric Fibers at Biological Temperatures and Low Concentrations,” Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 157, 1061-1066, 1988.), and, due to the E residue, on the pH (Dan W. Urry, ShaoQing Peng, Jie Xu, and David T. McPherson, “Characterization of Waters of Hydrophobic Hydration by Microwave Dielectric Relaxation,” J. Amer. Chem. Soc. 119, 1161-1162, 1997.).

Cross-linking by cobalt 60 of a relatively lower dose than the common 20 Mrads used for (GVGVP)˜200 (SEQ ID NO:25), say 2 to 8 Mrads, which with a lessened call for elastic modulus, fewer cross-links would allow for greater swelling for uptake of the FabECMP, discussed below. By adding a K (lysine, Lys) residue at a suitable interval, for example, (GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GKGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)n (SEQ ID NO:26), labeled ECMP1K3E/20F, cross-linking can be achieved by a water soluble carbodiimide as used in Dan W. Urry, Jie Xu, Weijun Wang, Larry Hayes, Frederic Prochazka, and Timothy M. Parker, “Development of Elastic Protein-based Polymers as Materials for Acoustic Absorption.” Mat. Res. Soc. Symp. Proc.: Materials Inspired by Biology, 774, 81-92, 2003 (See section Mechanical Properties of Cross-linked Fibers). The ratio, ECMP2E/10F:ECMP1K3E/20F can be varied to control extent of chemical cross-linking. The pH of the reaction mixture is also relevant. It should be noted that the pK of the carboxylate of ECMP2E/10F would be of the order of 6.2 (See FIG. 4) and that of the K residue will also be shifted toward physiological pH. These polymers can each be ionized, which leads to ion-pairing making ease of cross-linking to form an amide cross-link. A cross-linked 1:1 ratio would result in a nanoparticle for carrying cationic drugs. The D (aspartic acid, Asp) residue could, of course, also be used for the negative. Formation of an ECMPddnp for an anionic drug carrier would utilize K and/or R (argenine, Arg) and/or H (histidine, His) and would utilize fewer F residues, because of the lower solubility provided by the positive charges of K and/or R and/or H.

The loading of the nanoparticles with drug is assisted by determining loading profiles on non-cross-linked ECMP as demonstrated in FIG. 4 for a series of compositions of increasing hydrophobicity. The ECMP is dissolved in normal saline at pH 7.4. A small amount of drug is then added and the onset temperature of phase separation is determined as shown in FIG. 1B. This is continued stepwise for a given composition, e.g., K/0F, and then is repeated for a more hydrophobic polymer until a loading profile as in FIG. 4 is obtained. This determines which compositions can be used for the particular drug. This, with the pK of the functional group of the ECMP, provides information on the relative release rates that will occur, and with the release rate of one composition and the pK of each composition the release rate for each composition can be approximated. The chosen ECMP or the several of the most interesting ECMPs are then made into nanoparticles and the conditions for loading have been determined.
description.heading: Construction of Nanoparticles (ECMPddnp/p1p2) for Drug Delivery to Cells
description.p: Described herein are nanoparticles that are effective vehicles for delivering a therapeutic agent (e.g., a drug) to cells with a preferred release rate. While there are numberless means for achieving cell targeting and for constructing the ECMP nanoparticle, the method discussed below is one well-suited for the special properties of (GVGVP) (SEQ ID NO:4)-based ECMP. The ECMP are constructed by means of recombinant DNA technology, as described above. This allows simultaneous integration of the synthetic antigen-binding fragments, Fab 1 and Fab2, with the ECMPddnp. Following the Fab fragment labeling of Uysal et al (S. Uysal, V. Vasquez, V. Tereshko, K. Esaki, F. A. Fellouse, S. S. Sidhu, S. Koide, E. Peroz and A. Kossiakoff( ) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA, 2009, 106, 6644-6649. Protein Data Bank accession code 3EFF. In our example the compositions discussed above will be used, i.e., Fab1-(GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GKGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP (SEQ ID NO:26), labeled Fab1-ECMP1K3E/20F, and Fab2-(GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)2n (SEQ ID NO:27), labeled ECMP2(2E/10F), and the ECMP will be added to solution at a 1:1 ratio.

Using Quasi-elastic light scattering (QELS) and quenching, the correct conditions for achieving the desired particle size are determined (F. Sciortino, M. U. Palma, D. W. Urry and K. U. Prasad, “Nucleation and Accretion of Bioelastomeric Fibers at Biological Temperatures and Low Concentrations,” Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 157, 1061-1066, 1988). And conditions will be used that result in Fab1-Fab2 assembly to result in each Fab being attached to each other and to their respective chains.

The pseudo dimers composed of Fab1-(GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GKGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)n (SEQ ID NO:26), Fab2-(GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP GFGFP GEGFP GFGFP)2n(SEQ ID NO:27), coupled via the Fab1-Fab2 will be added to the weakly cross-linked nanoparticles described immediately above and incorporated into the weakly cross-linked nanoparticle by swelling and contracting.

claim.claim-text: wherein the modified therapeutic drug becomes an optimized therapeutic drug when the modified therapeutic drug upon administration to the cell decreases or prevents disruption of hydrophobic associations required for opening of a transit pathway within the exporter protein in the cell.
2. The process of claim 1, wherein the hydrophobicity ΔGHA of the optimized therapeutic drug is in a range of about −2 kcal/mol to about −20 kcal/mol.
3. The process of claim 1, wherein the exporter protein is an ATP-binding cassette protein.
4. The process of claim 1, wherein the cell is a Staphylococcus aureus cell and the exporter protein is Sav1866.
5. The process of claim 1, wherein the cell is a Salmonella typhimurium cell and the exporter protein is MsbA.
6. The process of claim 1, wherein the cell is a mammalian cell and the exporter protein is a P-glycoprotein.

7. The process of claim 1, wherein the decreasing or preventing disruption of hydrophobic associations comprises a simultaneous hydrolysis of two ATP molecules required for activity of the exporter protein in the cell.

8. An optimized therapeutic drug capable of reducing or preventing export of the therapeutic drug from a cell by an exporter protein, the optimized therapeutic drug prepared according to the process of claim 1.
9. The optimized therapeutic drug of claim 1, wherein the optimized therapeutic drug treats or prevents a cancer or an infection by a pathogen.
